results.title: Le Jour Se Leve = Daybreak
results.brief_description:
Poetic realism is a phrase often used in association with Carne’s work, and there could be no better example of this particular style than ‘Le jour se leve’. The setting is the ‘banlieue’ of a French industrial town - recreated in studio by Alexandre Trauner - and it would be hard to disagree with Gavin Lambert’s comment in ‘Sequence’ in 1948 that ‘there is no other film which has conveyed so intensely the drama, irony and nostalgias of urban life’. The narrative of ‘Le jour se leve’ condenses into one night action which covers a considerably longer period. On the night in question, Francois, a factory worker, has killed Valentin, who has a small music-hall act, and awaits the inevitable arrival of the police. In the meantime, he remembers the events which led up to the murder. Added to the abstract sense of determinism ‘Le jour se leve’ has a social and political dimension reflecting the climate of despair gripping France just prior to WWII. This feeling was particularly acute among the working class which had pinned so much hope on the Popular Front government, only to have them dashed by its too rapid disintegration and by the renewed offensives of the Right. The contrast with earlier films such as Renoir’s ‘Le crime de monsieur Lange’ (1935) and ‘La Marseillaise’ (1938), and even Duvivier’s ‘La belle equipe’ (1936), with their hope and optimism is both striking and depressing. The feeling of comradeship and solidarity is gone. The scene in which Arletty appears naked had to be cut to allow for the film to be released. ‘Le jour se leve’ was then regarded as ‘demoralising’ by the Vichy government which attempeted to ban all films affiliated with the ‘poetic realism’ style. The film was re-made as an American film noir as ‘The Long Night’ (1947) directed by Anatole Litvak, starring Henry Fonda.

Credits: Producer, Paul Madeux ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Jacques Viot ; photography, Curt Courant, Philippe Agostini ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photography, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Arletty, Jacqueline Laurent, Jules Berry, Bernard Blier.

results.title: La Tete Contre les Murs = the Keepers
results.brief_description:
Francois Gerane is convinced his father, a famous lawyer, has killed his mother. Using as a pretext one of Francois’s small misdeed, Maitre Gerane has the rebellious young man committed to a mental home. Much of Franju’s first feature was shot in an actual asylum. The film is essentially a plea for a more sensible treatment of the mentally ill and the emotionally distressed, calling for much-needed widespread reforms. ‘La tete contre les murs’ is surely the most beautiful French film made since the war, and possibly the most beautiful French film ever made.” Reference: POSITIF, 1/7/1959.

Credits: Producer, Jerome Goulven ; director, Georges Franju ; writers, Jean-Charles Pichon, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Eugene Schuftan ; music, Maurice Jarre ; assistant director, Jacques Rouffio ; camera assistant, Claude Zidi.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Mocky, Anouk Aimee, Pierre Brasseur, Charles Aznavour, Paul Meurisse, Jean Galland, Edith Scob, Jean Ozenne.

results.title: Le Jeu de L'amour et du Hasard
results.brief_description:
Silvia is about to get married. On the eve of meeting her fiance, she obtains her father’s consent to try an experiment: in order to observe her husband-to-be and to chose him freely, she is to swap identity with her servant, Lisette. Monsieur Orgon, Sylvia’s father accepts knowing full well that Dorante, Sylvia’s fiance has made a similar request and traded places with his butler, Arlequin.

Credits: Director, Marcel Bluwal ; photography, Andre Bac.
Cast: Danile Lebrun, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Francoise Giret, Claude Brasseur.

results.title: Le Chat et la Souris = the Cat and the Mouse
results.brief_description:
Richard, a philandering financier, is found murdered in his luxurious riverside mansion. Precious paintings have also disappeared. Inspector Lechat is put in charge of the investigation and immediately suspects Richard’s wife of eliminating her husband. As Lechat investigates her alibi, he becomes increasingly attracted to ‘the mouse’.

Credits: Director, Claude Lelouch ; writer, Claude Lelouch ; photography, Jean Collomb ; music, Francis Lai.
Cast: Serge Reggiani, Philippe Leotard, Michele Morgan, Valerie Lagrange, Jean-Pierre Aumont.

results.title: Hotel du Nord
results.brief_description:
In a cheap hotel near the canal St Martin, two star crossed lovers, Pierre and Renee, rent a room to execute their suicide pact. Pierre shoots Renee but lacks the courage to kill himself and runs away. Renee survives her ordeal and is adopted by the small community surrounding the hotel. She becomes a good friend of Monsieur Edmond, gangster and occasional pimp to Raymonde. Edmond falls in love with Renee and offers to run away with her to the Colonies. ‘Hotel du Nord’ is the second film in Carne’s trilogy of ‘poetic realist’ films, including ‘Quai des Brumes’ and ‘Le Jour se Leve’. In August 1939, on the eve of WWII, the French Ministry of Information drew up a list of 51 “depressing, morbid, immoral and bad for the youths” films, including ‘Hotel du Nord’. In the Carne canon, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is usually eclipsed by ‘Le Quai des Brumes’, ‘Le jour se leve’ (1939) and ‘Les Enfants du Paradis’ (1945), largely because of Prevert’s absence. Jeanson’s dialogue is indeed broader, the film more comic. In this respect, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is ‘theatrical realism’ rather than ‘poetic realism’. But in the interaction of set, camerawork and Maurice Jaubert’s restrained, moody music, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is typical of poetic realism. Its poetry is embodied in the superb set designed by Alexandre Trauner, a replica of one side of the Canal Saint-Martin, complete with bridges, punctuated by location shots of the canal and barges. The set is plainly artificial, yet still a microcosm of Paris which we enter with the young couple, the camera following them down the side of the bridge. (A reverse of this movement takes us out at the end of the film.) Graham Greene, who loved French cinema for knowing ‘the immense importance of the careful accessory’, once wrote, “in Hotel du Nord we believe in desperate lovers and the suicide pact on the brass bed in the shabby room, just because of the bicyclists on the quay, the pimp quarrelling with his woman in another room, and the First Communion party.” Social events such as strikes are a faint echo, as is the international situation (a young Spanish refugee is marginal to the story). Carne was more daring on the gender front. Characters may take the hackneyed appearance of pimps and prostitutes, but they are free of conventional morality. Edmond and Renee’s brief interlude is clearly sexual. When it is over (and although Edmond is smitten), they both shrug it off without guilt. Adrien is (for the time) a rare sympathetic portrayal of a gay character.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘Hotel du Nord’. Sight and Sound, March 1999: p. 41-42. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Henri Jeanson, Jean Aurenche ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Arletty, Annabella, Jean-Pierre Aumont, Bernard Blier, Andrex, Paulette Dubost, Jane Marken, Francois Perier, Andre Brunot.

results.title: Adieu Voyages Lents
results.brief_description:
This multi-parts film deals with the difficulties of sustaining a relationship under the pressure of modern life. In ‘Nuit, une guerre’, a couple’s amourous pursuits are interrupted by the noises coming from the street and the neighbouring appartments. In ‘Entrevu par l’indiscretion d’un Judas’, a man hears is own story told on the radio by a ‘talk-back’ programme listener and realises his wife has left him to seek refuge with her mother in the country. In ‘Adieu voyages lents’, Simone reveals to her mother the reason for leaving her husband and aborting the child she was expecting.

Credits: Director, writer, Marie-Genevieve Ripeau ; photography, Jean-Francis Gondre.
Cast: Andree Tainsy, Michele Simonnet, Evelyne Dandry, Jean-Francois Stevenin, Virgineie Thevenet.

results.title: Esther
results.brief_description:
Recorded at the Eglise Saint-Germain during the Festival du Marais. ‘Esther’ (1689) is a biblical tragedy complete with musical choral interludes composed by Jean-Baptiste Moreau, who would serve in this same role for Racine’s last play, Athalie. The play shows how Esther, the wife of the Persian king Ahasuerus (Xerxes I), saves the Jews from a massacre plotted by the king’s chief minister, Haman. With its three acts, chorus and transcendent message that God and truth can be made manifest on stage, Esther breaks sharply with Racine’s previous practice in tragedy. It is not one of his major works, despite the beauty of its choruses.” Reference: Encyclopedia Britanica. Online; http://www.eb.com

Credits: Director, Dominique Delouche ; photography, Emanuel Machuel ; music, Jean-Baptiste Moreau.
Cast: Andre Falcon, Liliane Nataf, Julien Bertheau, Claude Brosset.

results.title: Les Anges du Peche = Angels of the Streets
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Dominique Drouin and Roland Tual
results.brief_description:
Filmed during WWII, Robert Bresson’s first feature was shot entirely at night. Establishing a precedent that he would follow in his later films, Bresson utilises non-professionals in the leading roles. Rich young Anne-Marie thinks she has found her vocation when she joins a Dominican convent as a novice. The convent specialises in rehabilitating female prisoners, and Anne-Marie becomes especially fascinated with Therese, trying to get her to join the convent to redeem her for her sins - but Therese protests her innocence and refuses the offer. Upon her release, Therese kills her lover, and seeks refuge from the police in Anne-Marie’s convent. Further reading: Paul Schrader, “Transcendental Style in Film : Ozu, Bresson, Dreyer”, DaCapo, 1988. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producers, Dominique Drouin, Roland Tual ; director, Robert Bresson ; writers, Jean Giraudoux, (Rev. Pere) Raymond Leopold Bruckberger, Robert Bresson ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Jean-Jacques Grunenwald.
Cast: Renee Faure, Jany Holt, Sylvie, Marie-Helene Daste, Silvia Monfort, Mila Parely, Louis Seigner.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Bresson, Dominique Drouin and Roland Tual
results.description:
Filmed during WWII, Robert Bresson’s first feature was shot entirely at night. Establishing a precedent that he would follow in his later films, Bresson utilises non-professionals in the leading roles. Rich young Anne-Marie thinks she has found her vocation when she joins a Dominican convent as a novice. The convent specialises in rehabilitating female prisoners, and Anne-Marie becomes especially fascinated with Therese, trying to get her to join the convent to redeem her for her sins - but Therese protests her innocence and refuses the offer. Upon her release, Therese kills her lover, and seeks refuge from the police in Anne-Marie’s convent. Further reading: Paul Schrader, “Transcendental Style in Film : Ozu, Bresson, Dreyer”, DaCapo, 1988. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producers, Dominique Drouin, Roland Tual ; director, Robert Bresson ; writers, Jean Giraudoux, (Rev. Pere) Raymond Leopold Bruckberger, Robert Bresson ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Jean-Jacques Grunenwald.
Cast: Renee Faure, Jany Holt, Sylvie, Marie-Helene Daste, Silvia Monfort, Mila Parely, Louis Seigner.
